resource_definitions.display_name: ZeroMQ python bindings, with bundled copy of zeromq
resource_definitions.comment: DEPRECATED: use pyzmq instead!. In your install specs, you should refer to pyzmq-abstract rather than directly to this resource. This package provides zeromq python bindings along with a local copy of Zeromq itself, which is compiled during the install process. This is useful for older Ubuntu versions that do not have a zeromq apt package.

resource_definitions.display_name: ZeroMQ python bindings, with dependencies for Linux
resource_definitions.comment: In your install specs, you should refer to pyzmq-abstract rather than directly to this resource. This package provides zeromq python bindings. The driver just uses pip, but the dependencies include those needed to install the underlying zeromq libraries under ubuntu.

resource_definitions.display_name: ZeroMQ python bindings, packaged via macports
resource_definitions.comment: In your install specs, you should refer to pyzmq-abstract rather than directly to this resource. This package provides zeromq bindings via a macport. The version number refers to the python version, as the macports package is specific to that version.
If you need the ZeroMQ python bindings, reference this resource. It will pull in as a dependency the correct verion of the binding library as well as ZeroMQ itself.
Lxml installed via pip (works on MacOSX)

resource_definitions.display_name: lxml: XML processing library for python
resource_definitions.comment: pulls in either the ubuntu package or the pip package

This resource creates a file containing the master password. It has permissions of 0400, meaning it cannot be read by other users. This is useful with the --master-password-file option. Note that it doesn't actually force the use of the master password, so you need to include a resource that requires a password.
